Comment: I was pleased to see an attempt at the English. Often the play requires sharp thinking.
I reply with the common response.
This varation is tried...
...and I follow...
-SLAM! And now the opening book has been metaphorically thrown out the window. This isn't in the lines of the English at all, and now I must think of how to proceed next.
I really don't know how to proceed effectively here, so I try disrupting White's development.
To stop the pawn from capturing if an exchange. But, that diagonal is looking extremely dangerous...
So I prepare to advance both my development and the first attack of this match.
I honestly don't know why this was played, but the computer reasonably doesn't like this move...
Striking White with a queen pin already. The issue must be dealt with.
Forced.

Up until now, Computer Analysis had me at a +1.6 lead, but now it plummets down to .65. I really wanted to tempt a capture with the b pawn, but figured I still looked good, considering White hasn't touched the kingside at all this match so far.
Maybe I shouldn't have given up my dark squared bishop so soon after all...
So I decide to exchange again, hoping to hamper development even further. Obviously inaccurate.
And this was why. g7 is under a lot of delicate pressure at the moment...
Yet I continue telling myself that I can just keep trying to attack.
And now I fully understand I just should have stopped. I want to play Nf6, but if I do that, then Qe3+ forces me to lose castling rights regardless if I trade queens or not.
But since the White Queen sits there, I can't just leave my knight unsupported either, so I must do something. The knight must be defended.
And yet, now the kingside is ready to begin the harassment.
I must buy my knight enough time to escape the grip of the queen.
